content:
Even for me as a Mac user your problem is not clear besides that migration didn't succeed as it should have. Normally after replacing the Thunderbird folder in the user Library on the new Mac with the Thunderbird folder from the old Mac shouldn't create a new profile on TB start. Actually I don't know what happens now when you start TB.

I also compared your profiles.ini file with mine and noticed that the line "Locked=1" is missing under the [InstallAZSERTYJ] block. See a screen shot of my profiles.ini file
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Mapenzi said
Even for me as a Mac user your problem is not clear besides that migration didn't succeed as it should have. Normally after replacing the Thunderbird folder in the user Library on the new Mac with the Thunderbird folder from the old Mac shouldn't create a new profile on TB start. Actually I don't know what happens now when you start TB. I also compared your profiles.ini file with mine and noticed that the line "Locked=1" is missing under the [InstallAZSERTYJ] block. See a screen shot of my profiles.ini file

It shouldn't create a new profile, but for some reason, it does, at least in my case and that of some other users, even when the entire Thunderbird folder in the user Library has been replaced with the migrated one. As I described, I had to manually edit those two ini files in order to eliminate the new profile and show the migrated user as the only profile in the new installation.

I'm not sure why it was missing before, but here are the screenshots of my now active migrated ini files. The Locked line is now there.
creator: berkeleybernie

Try checking to see if Thunderbird has been programmed to automatically delete the emails.

Have you contacted your mail service provider about their retention policy on deleted mail. My guess is it is 30 days.

Folk appear to miss the whole IMAP syncronised means you get to keep what your provider decides you get to keep without the bounds of their retention policies.

content:
I'm not sure what exactly it is you're asking but the Help files state:

"Thunderbird does not currently offer a way to convert your existing IMAP account to POP3 or vice versa. In order to change your account to a different protocol, you will need to add the account onto Thunderbird again."

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
creator: @next

content: Set the account up as POP and it will download to PC and delete from server.
creator: davidsk

content: David, thanks so much for the reply. How do I do that? I don't see any place to make that change. Under server settings it does say "imap mail server" but I don't see any place where I can switch it to POP.
creator: service195

content: That's correct; you cannot convert IMAP to POP or POP to IMAP. Instead, you must create a new account. If the IMAP account is no longer needed, you can delete it.
creator: davidsk

content: OK, you lost me here. Forgive me, I'm going to (somewhat purposely) be obtuse. How do I do that? How do I have two accounts in the same program with the same email address? And then how do I import all my old messages to the new account?
creator: service195

content: For that matter, I don't even see a place where it allows me to create a new account.
creator: service195

content: just set it up. thunderbird can handle the same email address in multiple accounts. The POP account will automatically download all messages on the account. There is no need to import anything. If it's easier to understand, just delete the IMAP account first.
creator: davidsk

content: to create an account, click the hamburger menu and click 'create account. Or, with the menu bar, click File>new>email account
